ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Traumatic Tympanic Membrane Perforation (Right Ear)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: History of direct trauma with a cotton swab, immediate pain, and Type B tympanogram with abnormally large ear canal volume (3.7 mmho).

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Ossicular Chain Discontinuity
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Trauma can dislocate ossicles causing conductive loss; however, the high ear canal volume specifically confirms a perforation.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Hemotympanum
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Trauma can cause blood in the middle ear, but this typically presents with normal ear canal volume, unlike the high volume seen here.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To visually confirm the size and location of the perforation and check for infection or debris.
To assess middle ear status; high volume confirms perforation.
To quantify the degree of hearing loss resulting from the trauma.
To assess functional hearing ability and word recognition.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Findings are consistent with a traumatic tympanic membrane perforation in the right ear, evidenced by a mild conductive hearing loss and a flat tympanogram with large ear canal volume.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Type B with high equivalent ear canal volume (3.7 mmho), indicating perforation. Left ear: Normal Type A.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Mild low-frequency conductive hearing loss with air-bone gaps. Left ear: Normal hearing sensitivity.

tests.name: Wideband Acoustic Immittance
tests.result_summary: Reflectance asymmetry consistent with right middle ear pathology.

proposed_items: Referral to Otolaryngology (ENT) for otoscopic evaluation and management plan.
Annual hearing evaluation or sooner if symptoms change.
counseling_actions: Explain that the 'flat' pressure test with high volume confirms a hole in the eardrum caused by the cotton swab.
Advise strictly keeping the ear dry (use Vaseline-coated cotton ball or earplug when showering) to prevent infection.
Instruct to avoid forceful nose blowing to prevent forcing air/mucus into the middle ear.
Reassure that many traumatic perforations heal spontaneously, but monitoring is required.

escalation.rationale_short: To inspect the perforation, ensure no foreign body remains, and monitor for healing or need for surgical repair (tympanoplasty).

follow_up_plan.objective: To monitor for spontaneous closure of the tympanic membrane perforation and resolution of the conductive hearing loss.

expected_outcome: Spontaneous healing of the tympanic membrane perforation is likely.
Resolution of conductive hearing loss upon closure of the perforation.
If the perforation does not heal, surgical intervention (tympanoplasty) may be required.
